column1: Narcolepsy is a nervous system problem that causes extreme sleepiness and attacks of daytime sleep.
Most people with narcolepsy have daytime sleepiness and cataplexy.
People with narcolepsy fall asleep much faster than people without the condition.
- Antidepressant medicines can help reduce episodes of cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and hallucinations.
- Sodium oxybate (Xyrem) works well to control cataplexy.
Narcolepsy can usually be controlled with treatment.

Narcolepsy may lead to the following: - Trouble functioning at work - Trouble being in social situations - Injuries and accidents if attacks occur during activities - Side effects of medicines used to treat the disorder
